title: Fast Online Node Labeling for Very Large Graphs
abstract:
Abstract
This paper studies the online node classification problem under a transductive learning setting. Current methods either invert a graph kernel matrix with ùí™‚Äã(n3)ùí™superscriptùëõ3\mathcal{O}(n^{3}) runtime and ùí™‚Äã(n2)ùí™superscriptùëõ2\mathcal{O}(n^{2}) space complexity or sample a large volume of random spanning trees, thus are difficult to scale to large graphs. In this work, we propose an improvement based on the online relaxation technique introduced by a series of works (Rakhlin et¬†al., 2012; Rakhlin & Sridharan, 2015, 2017). We first prove an effective regret ùí™‚Äã(n1+Œ≥)ùí™superscriptùëõ1ùõæ\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{n^{1+\gamma}}) when suitable parameterized graph kernels are chosen, then propose an approximate algorithm FastONL enjoying ùí™‚Äã(k‚Äãn1+Œ≥)ùí™ùëòsuperscriptùëõ1ùõæ\mathcal{O}(k\sqrt{n^{1+\gamma}}) regret based on this relaxation. The key of FastONL is a generalized local push method that effectively approximates inverse matrix columns and applies to a series of popular kernels. Furthermore, the per-prediction cost is ùí™‚Äã(vol‚Å°(ùíÆ)‚Äãlog‚Å°1/œµ)ùí™volùíÆ1italic-œµ\mathcal{O}(\operatorname{vol}\left(\mathcal{S}\right)\log 1/\epsilon) locally dependent on the graph with linear memory cost. Experiments show that our scalable method enjoys a better tradeoff between local and global consistency.
